context_meta.title: Robots Learn To Move Like Humans Using Virtual Reality
context_meta.summary: The historic 1997 chess match left World Chess Champion, Garry Kasparov, defeated by an IBM computer named Deep Blue. During the final tense moments, Kasparov held his head in his hands and breathed into his clenched fists. He suddenly stood, conceded, and walked away from the chess board, towards the audience, arms held out, palms facing up. Deep Blue remained where it was, doing nothing. In fact, Deep Blue hadn't even been able to move a single one of its own chess pieces. A human surrogate had to move them. Arguably, the most astounding thing Kasparov did the whole match wasn't a genius chess move. It was this movement through our three-dimensional environment, walking off the stage and leaving

context_meta.title: Ikea sees 'massive opportunities' with artificial intelligence and virtual reality
context_meta.summary: Sweden's flatpack furniture giant is exploring how to make the best use of artificial intelligence (AI) and virtual reality. Speaking at the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos on Thursday, Jesper Brodin, CEO of Ikea, told CNBC: "(What) we haven't been able to do before is to find easier ways to connect with people so digital opens up massive opportunities for us." Brodin added a "major shift" in technology over recent years had prompted the furniture powerhouse to begin testing AI and virtual reality. Several retailers have been betting on AI as the tech becomes more sophisticated and as competition from the likes of Amazon grows even tougher.

context_meta.title: The Inpatient review – atmospheric virtual-reality chiller
context_meta.summary: PlayStation 4, Supermassive Games/Sony (PS VR headset required) It is a familiar horror movie setup: someone wakes to find themselves trapped in an asylum, with no memory of their past and a creepy doctor looming over them. But no matter how many times you've seen this on the big screen, it is very different when you're the one strapped in the chair. The Inpatient is a virtual reality thriller, which acts as a distant prequel to the 2015 horror adventure, Until Dawn. Having put on the required PlayStation VR headset, you find yourself in the gothic darkness of Blackwood Pines sanatorium, where ostensibly kindly Dr Bragg is administering some sort of treatment to retrieve your memories. context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: Sex dolls, live models make 'virtual intercourse' feel real
context_meta.summary: CamSoda is an adult-oriented live "camming" site dubbed "a virtual strip club with no cover" by its creators. The big idea might sound like something straight out of sci-fi, but here it is: Watch a private, one-on-one feed in virtual reality as you have sex with a "teledildonic" sex doll that transmits your tactile data to the model's matching vibrator (and vice versa). This push for virtual sex is the result of a new partnership between CamSoda and Abyss Creations, maker of top-of-the-line sex dolls called RealDolls. CamSoda calls the integration "virtual intercourse with real people," or VIRP (not to be confused with "vurp," which Urban Dictionary defines as "a burp laced with a little vomit").

context_meta.title: With Sundance, VR Is Officially a Film-Festival Staple. Now How Does It Make Money?
context_meta.summary: In 2014, I made a prediction. Virtual reality, I believed, would be the future of filmmaking. I was mostly correct; I was also terribly wrong. I was right in that dozens of filmmakers were going to embrace the 360-degree, immersive world of VR—this was obvious even from the half-dozen or so experiences tucked away in a small room at the Sundance Film Festival, where I had my epiphany. I was wrong in making it sound as though VR was going to up and replace film. It didn't. It likely won't. Ready Player One-style virtual worlds may never take the place of multiplexes, but immersive entertainment can change the landscape—if its creators can get people to pony up for it. context_meta.author: rocky.j.mountain
context_meta.title: Plex jumps into VR on Google Daydream headsets
context_meta.summary: The third pillar may be the most important for adoption, and that's social. Plex VR allows for up to four users at once, who can easily watch video streaming from a Plex Media Server while seeing each other's avatars, voice chatting or using the Daydream controller to toss things around and point out things on-screen. So far, many big media VR apps haven't included a social element, but for Plex owners who already have well-stocked media libraries, it could be an easy way to share viewing across any distance. The social setup includes a friends list with online statuses similar to PlayStation or Xbox Live, although of course, you can appear offline if you'd rather sit down for a solo session.

context_meta.title: Virtual reality helps U.S. Olympic ski team prepare for PyeongChang's great unknown
context_meta.summary: There are mountains in the Alps, from Austria to France, that veteran alpine racers have skied dozens of times over the years, so often they know every curve and can anticipate every bump. “There's some guys on tour for 15 years who have 60 runs down these hills,” said American skier Travis Ganong. “At that point, it's kind of ingrained — they know where to expend energy, where to save energy, where to push the line and where to hold back.” And then there's the downhill course for next month's PyeongChang Games, located in the Taebaek mountains about 90 miles east of Seoul, far removed from the World Cup circuit and foreign to most ski racers. A vague Nintendo patent for a head-mounted tablet holster that surfaced in late 2016 got the chatter going even further. context_meta.author: captainunderoos
context_meta.title: L.A. Noire: The VR Case Files review - Virtual reality improves an intriguing and involving detective yarn
context_meta.summary: LA Noire’s VR Case Files proves so entertaining because it understands virtual reality and all the strengths and foibles it entails. It's in the inherent silliness of strapping a hunk of electronics to your face and waving your arms around in the middle of your living room. And it's in the genuine transportive quality of diving into a fully immersive world and interacting with it close up. And my does LA Noire manage to conflate the two. By handing over almost full control of police detective Cole Phelps in 1940s Los Angeles, it allows you to be as silly or serious as you please. I have spent an undignified amount of time in Cole’s office, dancing in front of the mirror with my very fine hat, fingers bouncing in the air like a 90s rave while Cole’s face glares back with his grimace of mild annoyance. I’ve been entirely unprofessional at crime scenes, picking up pieces of evidence and chucking them at my non-plussed partner. I’ve patted witnesses on the head during interrogations and struggled to resist the urge to stick a finger up their nose. Rockstar facilitate all of this because, simply, virtual reality can be a good laugh and the developer is happy to let you interact with its world as you see fit. It doesn’t always react to you in the way you would expect, of course, VR worlds often don’t at this nascent stage of their evolution. But LA Noire also comes with the confidence that, when it comes to the more serious business of hunting out clues and taking down bad guys, Rockstar have provided an interesting, reactive and largely accomplished virtual reality adaption of their gumshoe adventure. The VR Case Files, exclusive to HTC's Vive headset, provides seven, occasionally streamlined scenarios spanning Cole’s meteoric rise in the LAPD from the original game, with each case handpicked to demonstrate different aspects of virtual reality. Each chapter can feel somewhat disjointed as Phelps leaps from keen patrolman to traffic cop to homicide and vice without the context of the original overarching narrative. But while some story details may pass by those who haven’t played LA Noire before, the episodic nature of the game means that each case is self-contained enough to follow from beginning to end. You hit the streets to investigate crime scenes, interrogate witnesses, get into fistfights, gun battles and the occassional car chase. What makes all of this work is that you are given almost full control over Cole. Very little of LA Noire is automated unless you want it to be, with (the real) you crouching down to pick up evidence, turning it over in your hands using the Vive motion controllers to find a crucial clue. 09 Jan 2018,10:43pm The biggest and best upcoming video games of 2018 You can stroll around areas by swinging your arms in a walking motion (or, if you so choose, can click on hotspots to teleport over). This is particularly evident in The Silk Stocking Murder, a brutal slaying which has you crouched over a corpse before following a grisly treasure hunt left by the killer. In the regular game, these could be somewhat laborious, clicking on different clues until you have enough to progress. In VR, this exploration makes a great deal more sense, with you peering into bins, following blood trails and feeling more involved in the pursuit. In essence, LA Noire’s gumshoe is the perfect fit for VR. While there are clear signs that this is an existing game adapted for the technology, with characters not reacting to some of your more eccentric behaviour, each aspect of LA Noire’s original goals are genuinely enhanced. Crime scene investigation is the most clear and present, while interrogation is a close second. The game’s facial motion-capture was extraordinary back in 2011 and still impresses today. Particularly when you get up close, carefully looking at tics and tells as you grill a witness, jabbing your pencil in their face if you fancy it. The action is good too. Fistfights are a little clumsy but pleasingly physical, with Cole accurately mimicking your moves as you duck in and out and swing a right hook at your quarry. Or you can open your hand and give them a good slap. Driving is perhaps the least successful aspect, with you mimicking a steering wheel with both hands and more likely to go barreling onto the sidewalk than keep in a straight line, But even this is laden with detail, with you getting in, turning the key and firing up the sirens yourself in a finely detailed 40s motor. But perhaps surprisingly, it is in gunfights that the VR Case Files impresses most. Again it is down to that autonomy. The opening tutorial has a brief shootout in which you must retrieve your shotgun from the trunk of your patrol car before dashing behind cover. You then physically lean round to get a bead on your target, holding the shotgun in both hands using the Vive controllers, before firing off a shot. You then chamber a new shell manually by pumping the shotgun, pulling your lead arm back with an endlessly satisfying “ch-chk” and reloading by reaching into your pocket and clicking each shell in while your cover is peppered by gunfire. The gunplay is expanded upon most in final vice case ‘A Different Kind of War’, but you do wish there was more. Shooting, that most video gamey of actions, is surprisingly underserved or undercooked in VR and LA Noire’s involving gunfights are some of the best examples there are. And this, perhaps, is where The VR Case Files raison d’etre becomes a bit clearer. This adaption of LA Noire is terrific fun, with Rockstar putting a lot of work into its detail and implementation. This is a game perfectly suited and definably improved by virtual reality. Its fleeting and occasionally disjointed nature, however, betrays that this is essentially a testbed. Rockstar trying its hand with the technology and seeing what it can do with its existing property. And if the developer is looking to branch out with all new virtual reality experiences, the evidence tne The VR Case Files is rather compelling.

context_meta.title: Nvidia updates software, says graphic chips not hit by flaws
context_meta.summary: "Our GPUs are immune," Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang said during an event at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, referring to graphics processing units, the chip maker's key product. Huang's comments illustrate how technology sellers from cloud-based datacenter providers to anti-virus companies are scrambling to guard against flaws disclosed last week in chips made by Intel and others. Security researchers revealed vulnerabilities, dubbed Meltdown and Spectre, that could let hackers steal passwords or encryption keys from central processing units (CPUs) made by Intel and rivals.

context_meta.title: Georgetown countering virtual reality with Jan. 20 'Actual Reality' promo
context_meta.summary: Capital One Arena's section 118 will play host to a unique promotion during Georgetown's Jan. 20 game against St. John's. The Hoyas announced that the area will transform into the “Actual Reality” seating section, where cell phones will be banned to encourage face-to-face interaction. Fans who elect to sit in the “Actual Reality” area will have to pick up their paper tickets at will call instead of using a smartphone to check in to the arena.
